title: Are David Foster Wallace books worth reading? - Quora

response.answer_text: Absolutely yes. And I would highly encourage you give them a try. And I would also highly encourage you to try looking at books from a slightly different point of view. Pick up a book and start reading. Give it 30–50 pages, see where it goes. If it’s boring you don’t feel bad about putting it down and looking for something else. I’ve done this several times. But back to DFW - I would start with some of his short story collections: “Oblivion”, “Brief interviews with hideous men”, then maybe move to some of his essays: “A supposedly fun thing I’ll never do again” or “Consider the Lobster”. Some of these works can be highly entertaining, eye-opening, educational, overly academic. Look around and see if you find anything you would appreciate. I’ve tried getting into his epic “Infinite Jest”, but 60–80 pages later I put it down. I’ll get to it sooner or later. But his unfinished novel “The Pale King” I highly enjoyed and appreciated. I haven’t read everything he wrote, but the above mentioned works I truly enjoyed and loved.

I cannot decide “worth” or “worthwhile” for you. However, there is a specific dilemma people face. Some novels can be recommended and that is because the novelist communicates with a foundation in the knowledge domains. However, when novels do not reflect the foundation in knowledge domains, the communication they offer is merely a reflection of the author’s general confusion. As a general guide, if you want to find a real “worth” or “worthwhile,” start exploring the realm of nonfiction.
